title: Broken beat
text:
Broken beat (sometimes referred to as "bruk") is an <a href="electronic%20music">electronic music</a> genre that can be characterized by <a href="Syncopation">syncopated rhythm</a> typically in <a href="Meter%20%28music%29">4/4 meter</a>, with staggered or punctuated snare beats and/or hand claps. It has heavily influenced music in the UK.
Artists in this area mostly have a <a href="drum%20and%20bass">drum and bass</a>, <a href="house%20music">house</a>, <a href="hip%20hop%20music">hip hop</a>, <a href="techno">techno</a> or <a href="acid%20jazz">acid jazz</a> background. Broken beat also has its roots in 1970s <a href="jazz%20fusion">jazz fusion</a> and has been influenced by artists such as <a href="Lonnie%20Liston%20Smith">Lonnie Liston Smith</a>, <a href="The%20Mizell%20Brothers">The Mizell Brothers</a> (producers for <a href="Donald%20Byrd">Donald Byrd</a>, <a href="Bobbi%20Humphrey">Bobbi Humphrey</a> and <a href="Johnny%20%26quot%3BHammond%26quot%3B%20Smith">Johnny Hammond</a> in the mid-1970s), <a href="Herbie%20Hancock">Herbie Hancock</a>, <a href="George%20Duke">George Duke</a>, and others. One might also hear echos of <a href="disco">disco</a>, 1980s <a href="contemporary%20R%26amp%3BB">contemporary R&B</a> and <a href="funk">funk</a> (<a href="Shalamar">Shalamar</a>, <a href="Prince%20%28musician%29">Prince</a>), early <a href="electronica">electronica</a> (<a href="Kraftwerk">Kraftwerk</a>), <a href="hip%20hop%20music">hip hop</a> ("<a href="Planet%20Rock%20%28song%29">Planet Rock</a>"), 1980s <a href="New%20wave%20music">new wave</a> (<a href="Depeche%20Mode">Depeche Mode</a>, <a href="New%20Order%20%28band%29">New Order</a>), house and techno in broken beat.
History.
Broken beat first appeared in the 1990s and was pioneered by <a href="Bugz%20in%20the%20Attic">Bugz in the Attic</a>, <a href="IG%20Culture">IG Culture</a>, and the release of the <a href="4hero">4hero</a> album, "<a href="Two%20Pages">Two Pages</a>," was influential on the emerging sound and scene. John Bush from All Music called it "about as fusion-soaked as it gets." Appearing in the western parts of <a href="London">London</a>, the genre is also referred to as "West London", mainly because Goya Music's offices were in London's <a href="Ladbroke%20Grove">Ladbroke Grove</a>, <a href="W%20postcode%20area">W11</a>, as were most of the participating artists' studios.
<a href="Bugz%20in%20the%20Attic">Bugz in the Attic</a>'s Neon phusion, <a href="Afronaught">Afronaught</a> & <a href="IG%20Culture">IG Culture</a> are credited with kick-starting the scene with numerous releases under various monikers, and the New Sector Movements releases for People Music. The sound created combined a variety of music styles including funk, soul, and hip-hop. The transition was to a more abstract form of drum and bass. Many artists that started releasing through <a href="4hero">4hero</a>'s Reinforced label are now considered pioneers of broken beat. Simultaneously, established <a href="techno">techno</a> artists like <a href="Carl%20Craig">Carl Craig</a> and <a href="Stacey%20Pullen">Stacey Pullen</a> experimented with the music they were making, trying to add <a href="jazz">jazz</a> elements and breaks to their sound. As the music is still based on classic Detroit techno and usually has a harder sound, it is sometimes referred to as "broken techno". This eclectic mixture was picked up by the Detroit and jazz affiliated UK techno producers <a href="Kirk%20Degiorgio">Kirk Degiorgio</a> or <a href="Kirk%20Degiorgio">As One</a> and <a href="Ian%20O%27Brien">Ian O'Brien</a>, who tried to form it into a more soulful variation which further influenced the development of the broken beat genre.
Scene.
Regular nights that play this genre of music include <a href="Co-op%20%28club%20night%29">Co-op</a>, the brainchild of <a href="Bugz%20in%20the%20Attic">Bugz in the Attic</a>'s <a href="Mark%20Force">Mark Force</a>, held at <a href="Velvet%20Room">Velvet Room</a>, and then a few years later moving on to <a href="Plastic%20People%20club">Plastic People</a>, a famous club located in London, for a number of years before re-launching at East Village - both in Shoreditch. In 2008 <a href="Afronaut">Afronaut</a> and Bruce Q (Liquid Fusion) teamed up for a monthly Co-Op sessions which was launched at Concrete in Birmingham, UK. Liquid Fusion ran every Sunday at The living Room (2000-2002) first then onto Zinc (2002-2008). It had a following of several Hundred weekly. Another night is Inspiration Information, previously at <a href="Notting%20Hill%20Arts%20Club">Notting Hill Arts Club</a> but now at East Village in Shoreditch.
